text: hi everyone welcome to IGCSE study buddy
where you can revise biology topics from
the Cambridge IGCSE syllabus
if you are enjoying these videos so far
please don't forget to hit the like
button and subscribe to our Channel
in this video you are going to learn
part 1 of topic 19
organisms and their environment
let's first dive into energy flow
energy flows through living organisms
starting with the Sun
plants use light energy from the Sun to
make their own food storing it as
chemical energy in their cells
animals then eat the plants gaining
energy from them
this energy is passed on when animals
are eaten by other animals
eventually energy is returned to the
environment through decomposition
this flow of energy is vital for the
survival and functioning of all living
organisms
so the sun is the principal source of
energy input to biological systems
before we go any further let's learn
some important definitions
a producer is an organism that makes its
own organic nutrients usually using
energy from sunlight through
photosynthesis
a consumer is an organism that gets its
energy by feeding on other organisms
a herbivore is an animal that gets its
energy by eating plants
a carnivore is an animal that gets its
energy by eating other animals
a decomposer is an organism that gets
its energy from Dead or waste organic
material
consumers may be classed as
primary
secondary
tertiary
and quaternary according to their
position in a food chain
a food chain shows the transfer of
energy from one organism to the next
beginning with a producer
here's an example of a simple food chain
in a grassland ecosystem
in this food chain the grass obtains
energy from the Sun
and is consumed by the rabbit the energy
stored in the grass is transferred to
the rabbit when it eats the grass the
fox then obtains the energy by preying
on the rabbit
so in a food chain the arrows between
each organism in the chain always point
in the direction of energy flow from the
food to the consumer
a food web is a network of
interconnected food chains
in this example the rabbit eats the
grass and the rabbit is then eaten by
the fox
also a snail eats the grass the trash
eats the snail and the fox then eats the
trash
two of these food chains have the same
producer and top predator
they can be joined together into a food
web
a trophic level is the position of an
organism in a food chain food web or
ecological pyramid
each step in the food chain represents a
different feeding level or trophic level
energy is transferred from one organism
to another as Predators consume their
prey
the energy flow continues as one
organism becomes food for another
organism at the next trophic level
the following are the trophic levels in
the food webs food chains and ecological
pyramids
producers we know that it's an organism
that makes its own organic nutrients
usually through energy from sunlight
through photosynthesis
primary consumers are herbivores they
feed on producers or plants
secondary consumers are predators that
feed on primary consumers
tertiary consumers are predators that
feed on secondary consumers
and quaternary consumers are predators
that feed on tertiary consumers
so in this example the plant will be the
producer the grasshopper is the primary
consumer
the mouse is the secondary consumer
the snake is the tertiary consumer
and the hawk is the quaternary consumer
now let's discuss the human impact on
food chains and food webs in a habitat
food webs are highly interconnected and
any changes in the population of one
species can have Ripple effects on other
organisms within the food web many
changes in animal and plant populations
are caused by human activities
over harvesting of food species this
disrupts the food chains because the
organisms that eat these species won't
have enough food to survive leading to
population declines
and the introduction of foreign species
to a habitat this creates competition
for resources which can harm the
existing species and disrupt the food
chain
both of these human-driven actions can
significantly alter the balance of
ecosystems
let's look at an example of how the
introduction of foreign species to a
habitat can affect it
let's say humans have introduced owls to
this habitat to eat the Grasshoppers
which say they consider to be pests and
want to reduce its population
so if the population of grasshoppers
decrease the population of grass would
increase as there are now fewer species
feeding off them
the population of frogs and mice would
decrease significantly as grasshoppers
are their only food source
the population of Threshers would
decrease slightly as they eat
grasshoppers as well but they have
snails as another food source
so we can see that when one trophic
level is damaged all that follow are
also impacted as the amount of food for
them decreases
now let's shift our Focus to ecological
pyramids
these pyramids are graphical
representations that show feeding
relationships of organisms at each
trophic level
first let's talk about pyramids of
numbers a pyramid of numbers shows the
number of organisms in each trophic
level of a food chain for example let's
construct a pyramid of numbers from this
food chain grass is eaten by
grasshoppers which are eaten by frogs
which are eaten by snakes this is how
the Pyramid of numbers will look for
this food chain with the producers at
the bottom and the consecutive consumers
on top
there is plenty of grass so the width of
the bottom level will be long
generally the larger and individual
organism is the less of them there are
so as you go higher up the food chain
the animals get larger and so the width
of the Box gets smaller a pyramid of
numbers will not always give a pyramid
shape
for example if we consider this food
chain we have one tree which is the
producer then we have caterpillars and
moving up the chain we have some buds so
in this case the Pyramid of numbers
won't be pyramid shaped this is because
the tree is one large organism which has
enough energy to support many smaller
organisms that is the caterpillars
a pyramid of numbers sometimes may be
misleading it may not depict the true
amount of energy in each trophic level
if we look at the second example it
makes it feel as if there may not be
enough producers to support the food
chain
next what are pyramids of biomass
biomass is the total dry mass of one
animal or plant species in a food chain
or food web a pyramid of biomass shows
the total mass of organisms in each
trophic level of a food chain rather
than the number of organisms pyramids of
biomass give a clearer picture of the
amount of plant or animal material at
each level of a food chain a pyramid of
biomass usually has a true pyramid shape
as biomass and energy is lost at each
level a pyramid of biomass therefore is
more useful as it gives an indication of
the amount of energy being passed on at
each stage of the food chain
for example let's construct a pyramid of
biomass and a pyramid of numbers from
this food chain and compare both aphids
feed on the oak tree and ladybirds feed
on aphids
so as you can see if we glance at the
Pyramid of numbers only it may appear as
if there may not be enough producers to
support this food chain but if you look
at the Pyramid of biomass in reality it
is apparent that the oak tree has more
than enough energy to support the food
chain so it's clearly more advantageous
to use a pyramid of biomass rather than
a pyramid of numbers to represent a food
chain
next pyramids of energy a pyramid of
energy shows the flow of energy at each
trophic level in an ecosystem
now in case you've not noticed there's a
loss of energy occurring at each trophic
level
starting from the producers energy is
transferred from one trophic level to
the next
as energy moves through trophic levels
it decreases at each trophic level 90
percent of the original energy is lost
only 10 percent of the energy is
available to the organism at the next
trophic level
this is because the energy is used for
respiration
movement
maintaining body temperature
and some parts of the food cannot be
digested
so the higher the trophic level the less
energy is available to them this is why
the transfer of energy from one trophic
level to another is often not efficient
so food chains usually have fewer than
five trophic levels because there is
significant energy loss at each level
this limited energy Supply makes it
difficult to sustain higher trophic
levels therefore food chains tend to be
shorter to maintain an adequate energy
flow
it is more energy efficient for humans
to eat crop plants than to eat livestock
that have been fed on crop plants
because energy is lost at each trophic
level when we eat crops directly we get
the energy stored in the plants more
efficiently but when we consume
livestock a lot of energy is lost
because it goes through an extra step of
transferring from Plants to animals
so by eating crops directly we save more
energy and are more efficient in our
food consumption
using a pyramid of energy is more
advantageous than pyramids of numbers or
biomass to represent a food chain
the pyramid of energy takes into account
the energy loss as it moves up the food
chain providing a more accurate
representation of decreasing energy
availability at higher trophic levels
this clear depiction of energy flow
makes it easier to understand how much
energy is available for each level in
the food chain
so that concludes part 1 of chapter 19
organisms and their environment
hope this video helped you please share
your thoughts and suggestions in the
comment section thank you for watching
and please don't forget to subscribe to
IGCSE study buddy for more biology
revision videos bye
